00018 /**
00019  @page pci_host OCTEON as a PCI host
00020 
00021 @section pci_host_intro 1. Introduction
00022 
00023     PCI host mode refers to when OCTEON is configured as the PCI bus arbiter
00024     controlling access to other devices. In this mode, OCTEON most closely
00025     resembles a desktop PC or a rack mount server. This document provides
00026     detailed information on the following aspects of OCTEON as a PCI host:
00027 
00028     - @ref pci_host_intro
00029     - @ref pci_host_hw_coverage
00030     - @ref pci_host_32bit
00031     - @ref pci_host_reset
00032     - @ref pci_host_config_space
00033     - @ref pci_host_io_space
00034     - @ref pci_host_memory_space
00035     - @ref pci_host_dma
00036     - @ref pci_host_interrupts
00037     - @ref pci_host_linux_config
00038     - @ref pci_host_tested_drivers
00039 
00040 @section pci_host_hw_coverage 2. Hardware Coverage of this Document
00041 
00042     This document does not cover all of the modes and registers available
00043     for the OCTEON PCI block. Only the most common setup used for host mode
00044     is described. For a complete PCI block reference, refer to the
00045     <b>OCTEON Hardware Manual</b>.
00046 
00047 @section pci_host_32bit 3. 32bit PCI Device Limitations
00048 
00049     Most PCI devices implement 32bit memory addressing and don't support full
00050     64bit accesses. This greatly constrains the address space available to
00051     OCTEON. Normally OCTEON can map devices to any 64bit address, but 32bit
00052     addresses must be mapped below 4GB. Adding this limitation to the fact
00053     that all BAR registers must not overlap (including OCTEON's), limits memory
00054     accesses to OCTEON through BAR1 only. BAR1 covers a 128MB range, divided
00055     into 32 4MB entries. Each entry may be mapped to an arbitrary OCTEON memory
00056     address. By convention, memory mapped through BAR1 is visible to PCI devices
00057     as the lower 128MB address region.
00058 
00059     -# OCTEON's BAR2 can't be used by 32bit devices. Since BAR2 is 39bits wide,
00060         it overlaps with all possible 32bit addresses when mapped at 0. The
00061         next possible mapping (1<<39) is outside of the 32bit address region.
00062     -# BAR1 entries are dynamically allocated as needed by calls to
00063         dma_map_single(). Overlapping regions are merged. If more than 32
00064         regions are needed, the kernel will panic.
00065     -# 64bit devices can use OCTEON's BAR2 to access all of memory. BAR2 must
00066         be mapped outside of the 32bit region.
00067 
00068 @section pci_host_reset 4. PCI Host Bus Reset and Initialization
00069 
00070     The recommended host mode PCI reset and initialization sequence requires
00071     quite a few register setups and strict timing constraints. Refer to
00072     <b>linux/kernel/linux/arch/mips/cavium-octeon/pci.c</b> for the exact
00073     code for PCI initialization. Below are the general steps for reference, but
00074     please use <b>pci.c</b> as the definitive reference.
00075 
00076     -# Reset the bus using CIU_SOFT_PRST
00077     -# Delay for 2ms
00078     -# Set the max write combining to 1 using NPI_CTL_STATUS
00079     -# Deassert PCI reset and advertize PCX Host Mode Device Capability
00080     -# Wait 2 ms after deasserting PCI reset
00081     -# Setup NPI_PCI_CTL_STATUS_2
00082     -# Wait 2 ms before doing PCI reads
00083     -# Read NPI_PCI_CTL_STATUS_2 to determine the PCI mode (64/32, PCI-X/PCI)
00084     -# Setup NPI_PCI_CFG01
00085         -# Memory Space Access Enable
00086         -# Master Enable
00087         -# PERR# Enable
00088         -# System Error Enable
00089         -# Fast Back to Back Transaction Enable
00090     -# Enable the internal arbiter using NPI_PCI_INT_ARB_CFG
00091     -# Disable the Master Latency Timer using NPI_PCI_CFG16
00092     -# Setup NPI_PCI_CFG22
00093         -# Master Retry Value [1..255] and 0=infinite
00094         -# AM_DO_FLUSH_I control
00095     -# Setup NPI_PCI_CFG56
00096         -# Data Parity Error Recovery Enable
00097         -# Relaxed Ordering Enable
00098         -# Maximum Memory Byte Count 1024B
00099         -# Maximum outstanding Split transactions to 3
00100     -# Setup OCTEON BARs for best performance
00101         -# NPI_PCI_READ_CMD_6 = 0x22
00102         -# NPI_PCI_READ_CMD_C = 0x33
00103         -# NPI_PCI_READ_CMD_E = 0x33
00104     -# Setup PCI memory accesses from OCTEON using NPI_MEM_ACCESS_SUBID3
00105         -# Endian-Swap on read.
00106         -# Endian-Swap on write.
00107         -# No-Snoop on read.
00108         -# No-Snoop on write.
00109         -# Relax Read on read.
00110         -# Relax Order on write.
00111     -# Remap the OCTEON BAR 0 to disable it.
00112     -# Remap the OCTEON BAR 1 to map 0-128MB
00113         -# Put in L2 cache.
00114         -# Byte swapping
00115     -# Remap the OCTEON BAR 2 to disable it.
00116 
00117 @section pci_host_config_space 5. PCI config space addressing
00118 
00119     PCI configuration space is accessed through OCTEON DID 3, SUBDID 1. The
00120     recommended method of referencing PCI configuration space is by
00121     constructing an OCTEON IO space address from the needed bus, device,
00122     function, and register. The following structure defines the format for the
00123     IO address.
00124 
00125 @code
00126     typedef union
00127     {
00128         uint64_t    u64;
00129         uint64_t *  u64_ptr;
00130         uint32_t *  u32_ptr;
00131         uint16_t *  u16_ptr;
00132         uint8_t *   u8_ptr;
00133         struct
00134         {
00135             uint64_t    upper       : 2;
00136             uint64_t    reserved    : 13;
00137             uint64_t    io          : 1;
00138             uint64_t    did         : 5;
00139             uint64_t    subdid      : 3;
00140             uint64_t    reserved2   : 4;
00141             uint64_t    endian_swap : 2;
00142             uint64_t    reserved3   : 10;
00143             uint64_t    bus         : 8;
00144             uint64_t    dev         : 5;
00145             uint64_t    func        : 3;
00146             uint64_t    reg         : 8;
00147         } s;
00148     } octeon_pci_address_t;
00149 @endcode
00150 
00151     To access a PCI device, set the fields of the address:
00152 @code
00153     octeon_pci_address_t pci_addr;
00154     pci_addr.u64 = 0;
00155     pci_addr.s.upper = 2;
00156     pci_addr.s.io = 1;
00157     pci_addr.s.did = 3;
00158     pci_addr.s.subdid = 1;
00159     pci_addr.s.endian_swap = 1;
00160     pci_addr.s.bus = bus_number;
00161     pci_addr.s.dev = device;
00162     pci_addr.s.func = function;
00163     pci_addr.s.reg = register;
00164 @endcode
00165 
00166     A read or write can then be performed using the *_ptr union members.
00167 
00168     @note PCI configuration space is in little endian format. All accesses
00169     need to be byte swapped before a store and after a load.
00170 
00171 @section pci_host_io_space 6. PCI port IO addressing
00172 
00173     All PCI IO port addressing is based at 0x00011a0400000000. To reference
00174     a PCI IO at 0x1234, you must read and write to 0x00011a0400001234.
00175 
00176     @subsection pci_host_io_space_1 Endian swapping
00177 
00178         OCTEON supports multiple swapping modes across the PCI bus. For host
00179         mode development, only mode 1 is useful.
00180 
00181     @subsection pci_host_io_space_2 Legacy ISA Devices
00182 
00183         Legacy PC devices, such as floppy controllers and CMOS RTCs, use IO
00184         ports below 0x1000. These ports are treated special by PCI bridges.
00185         In PCI bridge poweron defaults, these ports are normally blocked
00186         completely. If your board has a legacy PC device, such as a south
00187         bridge or video card behind a PCI bridge, the bridge must be specially
00188         configured. The bridge must be configured to pass all IO addresses
00189         0x0 to 0x1000 without any alias filtering. This is done in the Linux
00190         kernel for Intel and PLX bridge chips. This must be changed if your
00191         board uses multiple bridge chips or a different brand. The code for
00192         this can be found in <b>pci_chips.c</b>.
00193 
00194         Here is configuration changes made by Linux:
00195         -# 2 bytes at PCI config space 0x3e
00196             -# Disable bit 2, ISA port filtering
00197             -# Enable bit 3, VGA
00198             -# Enable bit 4, VGA Alias Filter
00199         -# 1 byte at PCI config space 0x1c and 0x30 to set the IO base to 0
00200 
00201     @subsubsection pci_host_io_space_3 VIA South Bridge
00202 
00203         The Via 686 series of south bridges, common on OCTEON motherboards,
00204         have an IO address limitation. These devices require that the IO
00205         ports be below 0x10000 for the PCI devices embedded in the chip.
00206         The recommended way of doing this is to start allocation IO ports
00207         at 0x4000. Keep in mind there are ISA emulated devices using the
00208         port number below 0x1000 inside these chips.
00209 
00210 @section pci_host_memory_space 7. PCI memory IO addressing
00211 
00212     OCTEON's PCI controller uses did=3, subdid=3,4,5 for PCI memory. In normal
00213     usage a single subdid is enough for all devices (0x00011b0000000000). It is
00214     important the PCI devices don't overlap with the OCTEON BAR registers. It
00215     is recommended that PCI devices start at 0x8000000, right after the 0-128MB
00216     BAR1 mapping.
00217 
00218     @subsection pci_host_memory_space_1 Endian swapping
00219 
00220         OCTEON supports multiple swapping modes across the PCI bus. For host
00221         mode development, only mode 1 is useful.
00222 
00223     @subsection pci_host_memory_space_2 OCTEON BAR setup
00224 
00225     The following code sets the OCTEON BAR registers in the recommended setup
00226     for PCI host mode.
00227 
00228 @code
00229     typedef union
00230     {
00231         uint32_t u32;
00232         struct
00233         {
00234             uint64_t reserved                : 14;      // Reserved
00235             uint64_t addr_idx                : 14;      // Address bits [35:22] sent to L2C
00236             uint64_t ca                      : 1;       // Set '1' when access is to be cached in L2.
00237             uint64_t end_swp                 : 2;       // Endian Swap Mode
00238             uint64_t addr_v                  : 1;       // Set '1' when the selected address range is valid.
00239         } s;
00240     } octeon_pci_bar1_indexx_t;
00241 
00242     // Write a 32bit value to the OCTEON NPI register space
00243     static void npi_write32(uint64_t address, uint32_t val)
00244     {
00245         volatile uint32_t *ptr = (volatile uint32_t *)(address ^ 4);
00246         *ptr = val;
00247     }
00248 
00249 
00250     // Read a 32bit value from the OCTEON NPI register space
00251     static uint32_t npi_read32(uint64_t address)
00252     {
00253         volatile uint32_t *ptr = (volatile uint32_t *)(address ^ 4);
00254         return *ptr;
00255     }
00256 
00257     // Remap the OCTEON BAR 0 to disable it. We'll map to to the highest possible address
00258     npi_write32(OCTEON_NPI_PCI_CFG04, 0xffffffff);
00259     npi_write32(OCTEON_NPI_PCI_CFG05, 0xffffffff);
00260 
00261     // Remap the OCTEON BAR 1 to map 0-128MB
00262     octeon_pci_bar1_indexx_t bar1_index;
00263     int index;
00264     bar1_index.u32 = 0;
00265     bar1_index.s.ca = 1;            // 1 = Put in L2 cache
00266     bar1_index.s.end_swp = 1;       // 1 = Byte swapping
00267     bar1_index.s.addr_v = 1;        // This entry is valid
00268     for (index=0; index<32; index++)
00269     {
00270         bar1_index.s.addr_idx = index;
00271         npi_write32(OCTEON_NPI_PCI_BAR1_INDEXX(index), bar1_index.u32);
00272     }
00273     npi_write32(OCTEON_NPI_PCI_CFG06, 0);
00274     npi_write32(OCTEON_NPI_PCI_CFG07, 0);
00275 
00276     // Remap the OCTEON BAR 2 to disable it. We'll map to to the highest possible address
00277     npi_write32(OCTEON_NPI_PCI_CFG08, 0xffffffff);
00278     npi_write32(OCTEON_NPI_PCI_CFG09, 0xffffffff);
00279 @endcode
00280 
00281 @section pci_host_dma 8. DMA Memory Coherency
00282 
00283     PCI DMA accesses go through the OCTEON's L2 cache just like any other
00284     memory access. The L2 performs all core invalidates necessary to make sure
00285     memory is always coherent. This means that drivers don't need to worry about
00286     cache coherency.
00287 
00288 @section pci_host_interrupts 9. PCI Interrupts
00289 
00290     The PCI INT-A,B,C,D interrupt lines route to CIU_INTX_EN0 bits 36-39. The
00291     status of these lines can be monitored using CIU_INTX_SUM0. Depending
00292     on the setup of CIU_INTX_EN0, these will be routed to Mips interrupt 2 or 3.
00293     Under Linux, these are always mapped to Mips interrupt 2, which is then
00294     decoded into Linux IRQ 44-47 based on the status of CIU_INTX_SUM0.
00295 
00296     @note PCI interrupts are <b>level triggered active low</b>. Don't connect
00297         active high or edge triggered devices to the PCI interrupts. Use GPIO
00298         pins for these devices.
00299 
00300     @subsection pci_host_interrupts_1 Interrupt routing
00301 
00302         To determine the interrupt line used for each device, you must consult
00303         with the board schematic. Unfortunately most designers do not follow
00304         the PCI spec guidelines for choosing interrupt lines. This means the
00305         only way to determine where each interrupt line goes is through the
00306         board schematic. This board specific setup is performed for Linux in
00307         @b pcibios_map_irq and @b octeon_get_pci_interrupts
00308         (linux/kernel/linux/arch/mips/cavium-octeon/{pci.c, hal.c}).
00309 
00310     @subsection pci_host_interrupts_2 GPIO Interrupts
00311 
00312         The GPIO pins should be used for interrupts from any devices that do
00313         not follow the PCI specification for interrupt generation. Each GPIO
00314         pin can be independently configured for edge / level triggered as well
00315         as active high/low. In addition, these pins have configurable debouce
00316         logic per pin. It is recommended that devices be hooked to GPIO 15,
00317         then 14, and so on. This allows boards to work properly with OCTEON
00318         Pass 1 as well as newer chips.
00319 
00320     @subsection pci_host_interrupts_3 VIA South Bridge Interrupts
00321 
00322         The Via 686 series of south bridges are designed to be directly
00323         connected to x86 processors. These devices do not create standard
00324         PCI interrupts. <b>The 686 interrupts are active high</b>. This
00325         interrupt line must be connected to an OCTEON GPIO register, preferably
00326         GPIO15. Inside the 686 chip, the original PC 8259 dual interrupt
00327         controllers is emulated. In order for interrupts from the 686 chip
00328         to work, both the master and slave 8259s must be programmed. Refer
00329         to <b>linux/arch/mips/cavium-octeon/i8259.c</b> for details.
00330 
00331     @subsection pci_host_interrupts_4 Interrupt Affinity
00332 
00333         Interrupts are normally handled by the cpu that loads the driver. This is
00334         normally cpu 0. This can be changed through the <b>/proc/irq</b> interface.
00335         Writing a cpumask to <b>/proc/irq/#/smp_affinity</b> will route an interrupt
00336         to the cores in the mask.
00337 
00338         For example, lets say this is what "cat /proc/interrupts" shows:
00339 @verbatim
00340                   CPU00      CPU01
00341           3:        215        277          Octeon  IPC
00342           7:     404782     404029          Octeon  timer, Perfcounter
00343          23:      15242      15203          Octeon  Ethernet
00344          42:          0        143          Octeon  serial
00345          45:     987869          0          Octeon  eth0
00346          54:          0          0          Octeon  ECC
00347          64:          0          0          Octeon  dwc_otg, dwc_otg_pcd, dwc_otg_hcd:usb1
00348 @endverbatim
00349 
00350         To switch the interrupts for eth0 to the second core:
00351 @verbatim
00352         echo 2 > /proc/irq/45/smp_affinity
00353 @endverbatim
00354 
00355         To have both cores process the interrupt:
00356 @verbatim
00357         echo 3 > /proc/irq/45/smp_affinity
00358 @endverbatim
00359 
00360 @section pci_host_linux_config 10. Configuring Linux for PCI Host
00361 
00362     Linux uses the bootloader flag CVMX_BOOTINFO_CFG_FLAG_PCI_HOST to
00363     determine if the board supports PCI in host mode. If this bit is set in
00364     the config_flags field, PCI is setup and enumerated. If it isn't set,
00365     Linux doesn't configure PCI.
00366 
00367 @section pci_host_tested_drivers 11. Tested Linux Device Drivers
00368 
00369     The following Linux device drivers are known to work with OCTEON in host
00370     mode. Many other drivers should work without modification, but only these
00371     have been tested so far.
00372 
00373     - Via Rhine II 100Mbps Ethernet
00374     - Realtech 8139D 100Mbps Ethernet
00375     - NEC D720100 USB 2.0
00376     - Intel E1000 1Gbps Ethernet (Wired and Fiber)
00377     - CMD640 Parallel IDE Controller
00378     - Silicon Motion SATA controller
00379     - AirLink AWILL3026/NA USB 802.11b/g
00380     - USB Mass storage devices
00381 
00382 */
